subject: Re: [junit] Javadocing test case and other test classes?
msgSnippet: ...  ... The standard answer is that comments are a way to deodorize a code smell and that you can often make the smell go away rather than cover it up
messageBody:
Kevin Klinemeier wrote:
> public void testMultipleCustomerPurchaseOrderEntriesForOneSalesOrderLine();
>
> The test method is about a page of code, on the heavy side of the
> average for our codebase but nothing gigantic. Still, I felt it
> needed a comment in plain english, which is:
>
> Tests that this mapper creates multiple customerPurchaseOrder entries
> associated with the sales order line, when multiples exist across line
> items.

<snip>

> Ultimately, why wouldn't you want to write actual sentences? I like
> Java a lot, but English was my first language.
>

The standard answer is that comments are a way to deodorize a code smell
and that you can often make the smell go away rather than cover it up
with a comment. Of course, this isn't always possible and sometimes not
even desirable in a test.

Sometimes it is though. I find that when I have a lot of page long
tests, there is a lot of duplication between the tests - which hurts
maintainability and readability. EXTRACT METHOD can help with both.

I am imagining something like this :

public void testMultipleCustomerPurchaseOrderEntriesForOneSalesOrderLine()
{
createSalesOrderLine(...);
addCustomerPurchaseOrder( .... X );
addCustomerPurchaseOrder( .... Y );
assertSomethingAboutOrders( ...expected ...);
}

Any chance we can see the test ?

(also) Kevin
